name: sarek-somatic-variants
title: Sarek Somatic Variant Calling
description: Tumor-normal somatic variant calling from WGS/WES. Detects cancer mutations using Mutect2, Strelka2, and other somatic callers with best-practice tumor analysis. Samplesheet format: `sample,lane,fastq_1,fastq_2`
content:
Sarek Somatic Variant Calling

Somatic variant calling identifies mutations acquired in cancer cells that are not present in the patient's germline DNA. By comparing tumor and matched normal tissue, we detect driver mutations, resistance variants, and therapeutic targets.

What are Somatic Variants?

Somatic mutations arise in specific cells/tissues during a person's lifetime (not inherited). In cancer, these mutations drive tumor growth, metastasis, and drug resistance. Unlike germline variants, somatic mutations cannot be passed to offspring.

Why Tumor-Normal Analysis?

  • Distinguish Somatic from Germline: Mutations in tumor but not normal = cancer-specific
  • Reduce False Positives: Filter out common germline variants
  • Detect Driver Mutations: TP53, KRAS, EGFR, BRAF, PIK3CA
  • Identify Actionable Targets: Mutations treatable with targeted therapy
  • Tumor Evolution: Track clonal architecture, heterogeneity
  • Resistance Mechanisms: Acquired mutations after treatment

Pipeline Workflow

  1. Preprocessing: Align tumor + normal with BWA-MEM2
  2. Mark Duplicates: Remove PCR artifacts
  3. Base Quality Recalibration: GATK BQSR
  4. Somatic Variant Calling: Mutect2, Strelka2, Manta (SVs)
  5. Filtering: Panel of normals, contamination estimation
  6. Annotation: VEP adds clinical significance, hotspots
  7. CNV Calling: CNVkit, ASCAT for copy number alterations
  8. QC Report: MultiQC with tumor purity, ploidy estimates

Somatic Variant Callers

GATK Mutect2 (recommended):

  • Gold standard for tumor-normal calling
  • Uses panel of normals (PoN) to filter artifacts
  • Estimates contamination, allele fractions
  • Detects low-frequency variants (5-10% VAF)

Strelka2:

  • Fast, accurate somatic SNV/indel caller
  • Good sensitivity for low-VAF variants
  • Lower resource usage than Mutect2

Manta:

  • Structural variant (SV) caller
  • Detects deletions, duplications, inversions, translocations
  • Important for gene fusions (BCR-ABL, EML4-ALK)

ASCAT / CNVkit:

  • Copy number variation (CNV) detection
  • Estimates tumor purity, ploidy
  • Identifies amplifications (ERBB2, MYC) and deletions (CDKN2A)

Scientific Applications

Precision Oncology:

  • Identify actionable mutations for targeted therapy
  • EGFR mutations: Lung cancer → erlotinib, osimertinib
  • BRAF V600E: Melanoma → vemurafenib, dabrafenib
  • HER2 amplification: Breast cancer → trastuzumab
  • KRAS G12C: Colorectal, lung → sotorasib

Tumor Profiling:

  • Molecular subtyping (luminal, basal, HER2+)
  • Mutational signatures (UV, tobacco, APOBEC, MMR deficiency)
  • Tumor mutational burden (TMB) → immunotherapy response
  • Microsatellite instability (MSI) → Lynch syndrome, immunotherapy

Clonal Evolution:

  • Primary tumor vs metastasis
  • Pre-treatment vs post-relapse
  • Clonal vs subclonal mutations
  • Tumor heterogeneity

Liquid Biopsy:

  • Circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in blood
  • Minimal residual disease monitoring
  • Early detection of recurrence

Key Cancer Genes

Tumor Suppressors (loss-of-function):

  • TP53: Mutated in 50% of cancers
  • PTEN: PI3K pathway inhibitor
  • RB1: Cell cycle regulator
  • APC: Colorectal cancer

Oncogenes (gain-of-function):

  • KRAS, NRAS, HRAS: RAS pathway (30% of cancers)
  • EGFR: Receptor tyrosine kinase (lung, glioblastoma)
  • BRAF: MAPK pathway (melanoma, colorectal)
  • PIK3CA: PI3K pathway (breast, colorectal)
  • MYC: Transcription factor (often amplified)

Variant Allele Fraction (VAF)

VAF = % of reads supporting the variant:

  • ~50%: Heterozygous clonal mutation (early)
  • ~100%: Homozygous or LOH (loss of heterozygosity)
  • 5-40%: Subclonal mutation (late, heterogeneous)
  • <5%: Very low frequency (minor clone, sequencing noise)

Sequencing Requirements

Tumor TypeCoverageSensitivity
WGS Tumor60-100XDetect ~5% VAF variants
WGS Normal30-40XFilter germline
WES Tumor200-300XHigher depth for exons
Liquid Biopsy1000-5000XUltra-deep for ctDNA

Quality Metrics

  • Tumor Purity: % tumor cells (affects VAF interpretation)
  • Ploidy: Average DNA copies per cell
  • Contamination: Cross-sample contamination estimate
  • Ti/Tv Ratio: ~2.5-3.0 for somatic variants
  • Mutational Burden: Mutations per Mb (TMB)

Filtering Strategies

Panel of Normals (PoN):

  • Collection of normal samples processed identically
  • Filters recurrent technical artifacts
  • Removes germline variants in genes like olfactory receptors

Common Artifacts:

  • FFPE artifacts (C>T transitions)
  • Oxidation artifacts (8-oxoG)
  • Alignment errors in homopolymers, STRs

Clinical Actionability

OncoKB / CIViC annotation levels:

  • Level 1: FDA-approved drug for this mutation
  • Level 2: Standard care biomarker
  • Level 3: Clinical evidence (trials)
  • Level 4: Preclinical evidence

Example Actionable Mutations

GeneMutationCancerTherapy
EGFRL858R, exon 19 delNSCLCErlotinib, osimertinib
BRAFV600EMelanoma, CRCVemurafenib, dabrafenib
KRASG12CLung, CRCSotorasib, adagrasib
HER2AmplificationBreast, gastricTrastuzumab
ALKFusionNSCLCCrizotinib, alectinib

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with columns:

  • patient: Patient ID
  • sample: Sample ID (tumor, normal)
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ
  • status: 0 (normal) or 1 (tumor)

Key Outputs

  • Somatic VCF: Tumor-specific variants
  • Annotated VCF: With OncoKB, CIViC, COSMIC
  • CNV Calls: Copy number alterations
  • SV Calls: Structural variants, gene fusions
  • Purity/Ploidy: Tumor characteristics
  • MAF File: Mutation Annotation Format for visualization
  • MultiQC Report: Comprehensive QC

Perfect for: Precision oncology • Tumor profiling • Actionable mutations • Clinical trials • Drug resistance • Tumor evolution
